thread.title_full: How’s this for sexual healing? | New York Post

author: Natalie O'Neill
title: How’s this for sexual healing?
text:
It’s streetwalkers meets men-with-walkers.
A German lawmaker wants the government to pay for elderly and poor people to have sex with prostitutes as part of a controversial health-care package, according to reports Monday.
Elizabeth Scharfenberg of the Green Party says doctors should be given the right to write free prescriptions for sex in the country, where prostitution is legal and less taboo than in the U.S.
“I can imagine a public financing of sexual assistance,” Scharfenberg said in an article in the Welt am Sonntag newspaper. “Municipalities could discuss appropriate offers on site and grants they would need.”
She aims to pay for disabled people and nursing-home residents to get laid, according to a translation by Time magazine . The financial model would be similar to one set up in the Netherlands, she said.
The sexual healing bill would require patients to prove they can’t get bedroom action without paying for it — and that they can’t afford it.
Patients must show: “They are unable to achieve sexual satisfaction in other ways, as well as to prove they are not able to pay sex workers on their own,” the bill states, according to The Daily Mail .
Brothels in Germany recently began offering “sexual assistance” to people in nursing homes, those who suffer from dementia and the disabled, the paper reported.
The sexual services range from “affectionate touching” — known in the U.S. as sexual surrogacy — to straight up intercourse and kink.
Sexual assistance can be physically and emotionally healing, some experts say.
“In Germany in recent years we have seen the advent of sexual companions, especially trained in relation to the sexual needs of elderly men and women,” sex coach and author Vanessa del Rae told the Daily Mail.
“[The workers] know the handicaps, the shyness and shame which come with old people,” said del Rae, who is a former nurse.
Prostitution has been legal in Germany since 2002.
